div.head: The Thousand Buddhas of the Fortunate Kalpa
div.p:
A. In Toh 94, Bhadrakalpika
-- beginning of 2nd chapter (F.17.a-b), a Dharmabhāṇaka called rin po che’i lus mtha’ yas par grags pa spyod pa’i mdzod, teaches the teachings (in particular the samādhi being described in this sūtra) of the Buddha gser sdug mdzes pa rnam par nges pa’i ’od kyi gzi brjid kyi rgyal po to a cakravartin king called skye bo mang po mngon par dga’ zhing mya ngan med pa’i nga ro. The Dharmabhāṇaka, the King, the king’s 1,000 sons, and a whole group of attendants then practise and accumulate virtue for 80 kalpas.

The Dharmabhāṇaka was none other than Amitāyus in a previous life; the King becomes Akṣobhya; and the 1,000 princes become the 1,000 buddhas of the Fortunate Eon. These are listed by name from F.86b – 101.b.

B. In Toh 47, Tathāgatācintyaguhyanirdeśa
-- fifth chapter, F.117.b – 125.b:

Eon “Beautifully Illuminating” (mdzes par snang ba)
Universe “Fully Adorned” (rnam par brgyan pa)
Buddha “King Set with Jewels of Infinite Qualities” (yon tan mtha’ yas rin chen sna tshogs bkod pa’i rgyal po)
Intermediate 4-continent world “Beautifully Illuminating” (mdzes par snang ba)
Central city and palace: “The Pure” (rnam par dag pa can)

King Dhṛtarāṣṭra (yul ’khor srung) has 700,000 queens (all bodhisattvas) and 1,000 sons (bu stong du tshang ba). Two are born miraculously, Dharma Mind (chos sems pa) and Dharmamati (chos kyi blo gros) and receive teaching on the nature of phenomena. The king puts all the names of his sons in a precious vase and makes offerings for seven days, then pulls out names.

item.p: 1. Prince Pure Intelligence (gzhon nu rnam par dag pa’i blo gros), who is predicted to be Krakucchanda.
2. Victorious Army (gzhon nu rnam par rgyal ba’i sde) – Kanakamuni
…and so forth up to 21 Tathāgatas (note that after 6, seng ge, the names are not the same as in the Bhadrakalpika).
last Matyananta (thams cad kyi tha chungs ] blo gros mtha’ yas) – Adhimukta (mos pa)

div.p: chos sems pa vows to become Vajrapāṇi for all of them, and Dharmamati will request all of them to turn the wheel of Dharma, as Mahābrahmā.
Dhṛtarāstra was previous life of Buddha Dīpaṃkara.

This is the version mentioned in the “empowerment of the thousand buddhas” for Ratnalingpa’s thugs rje chen po gsang ba ’dus pa (Rin chen gter mdzod new Shechen edition vol. ’a, p. 291) which lists their names, ending in snang mdzad (Roca) rather than Adhimukta. There are (?) other rituals and empowerments based on the theme in the Tibetan literature.

C. In the Karuṇapuṇḍarika (Toh 112)
-- the best known version? The story of Samudrareṇu and his sons: most of the sūtra’s narrative takes place in the distant past and concerns the cakravartin king Araṇemin, his thousand sons, his chief court priest Samudrareṇu, and Samudrareṇu’s eighty-one sons and his disciples. One of Samudrareṇu’s eighty-one sons is the Buddha Ratnagarbha, who prophesies the buddhahood of all these individuals. He states that King Araṇemin will become the Buddha Amitābha, Samudrareṇu will become Śākyamuni in our fortunate eon, and 999 of Samudrareṇu’s disciples plus his five attendants will become the other 1,004 buddhas of our eon.

D. In the Vimalakīrtinirdeśa , (Toh 176)
-- in the final chapter, 12.6-18.

In this version the origin takes place in an eon called Vicaraṇa, a universe called Mahāvyūha, featuring a buddha Bhaiṣajyarāja and King Ratnacchattra, one of whose sons Candracchattra, who became the next buddha after Bhaiṣajyarāja and taught for ten short eons.
Ratnacchattra was a previous life of the Tathāgata Ratnārcis (buddha of a western buddhafield acc to PP); the thousand sons, of the buddhas of the Fortunate Eon; and in particular Candracchattra, of Śākyamuni.
The last buddha is mentioned as Roca (snang mdzad).

E. In the Prajñāpāramitā in Twenty-five Thousand Lines (nyi khri, Toh 9)
-- end of chapter 33: 20,000 bodhisattvas are prophesied as buddhas in the Fortunate Eon.
